Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The origin of the metal-poor halo of the Milky Way
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will reconstruct the origin of the Milky Way's stellar halo by studying the chemical compositions of its constituents: extremely metal-poor stars in the halo itself and metal-poor stars in the least luminous dwarf galaxies orbiting about the Galaxy. She will leverage her access to the Australian SkyMapper Telescope to identify large numbers of stars in the Galactic halo, and combine these data with high spectral resolution observations using the Magellan telescope. She will therefore assemble a legacy data set of the most metal-poor stars in the galaxy, which will substantially advance our understanding of the early universe and the build-up of the old stellar halo of the Milky Way. In concert, the PI will produce accompanying theoretical frameworks that allow for a cosmologically informed interpretation of stellar abundance measurements. The program has three specific goals: (1) to perform stellar archaeology, giving us new constraints on the major physical processes that drove early star formation; (2) to perform dwarf-galaxy archaeology, allowing us to better understand galaxy formation; and (3) to determine the role of metal-poor stars as tracers of the accretion history of the Milky Way halo.

The PI will disseminate her research to a broad audience by publicly releasing her new measurements on the chemical abundances of stars. She will also collaborate closely with the MIT Online Science, Technology, and Engineering Community (MOSTEC), which is a free online education and enrichment program for high school seniors from underserved and underrepresented communities. Finally, the PI will also create a series of short videos designed to show students how to observe with the Magellan telescopes, thereby encouraging them to be informed participants in how astronomical data are gathered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this NSF CAREER award have been about reconstructing the origins of the Milky Way stellar halo by studying the chemical compositions of two groups of its constituents: extremely metal-poor stars in the halo, and metal-poor stars with located in the least luminous dwarf galaxies that orbit the Galaxy. Using the Magellan telescope, we have obtained high-resolution spectra (R∼30,000) for numerous newly discovered stars, including several record holders for the most metal-poor stars in the halo and different dwarf galaxies. Detailed chemical abundance analyses of these stars have revealed, among others, the following discoveries:

- The most iron-poor star with [Fe/H]<-7.3, a star with a measured iron abundance of [Fe/H]=-6.3, as well as notable other stars with -6<[Fe/H]<-4.

- The r-process galaxy Reticulum II, the discovery of dozens of strongly enhanced r-process stars as part of the R-Process Alliance efforts, several of them with detections of thorium and uranium, and the first star with a combined signature of the r- and the s-process.

- The ultra-faint dwarf galaxy Segue 1 as one of the chemically most primitive systems formed in the universe, and numerous very and extremely metal-poor stars in a variety of dwarf galaxies.

In addition, theoretical studies of the formation scenarios of the first stars and most metal-poor stars, as well as the subsequent evolution of their early host galaxy and accretion by the Milky Way have been carried out. This yielded estimates for the numbers of low-mass first stars and r-process enhanced stars in the halo. Other works addressed the chemical evolution of different types of metal-poor stars.

The results have enabled detailed look into the physical processes that governed the first chemical enrichments events, early star formation, and to what extent early analogs of the surviving ultra-faint dwarf galaxies played a significant role in building the metal-poor halo of the Galaxy.

A variety of video clips showcasing what astronomers do when they go observing with big telescopes have been created at Las Campanas Observatory. They give the public an inside peek into the day and night work at an observatory that is otherwise inaccessible to non-scientists. An additional light board video series highlighting the science of old stars, how they are observed with spectroscopy and observing with large telescopes was created to provide additional background material. The videos have been used in an MIT online astronomy summer program for underserved high school students and been shown numerous times in public and educational talks by the PI to engage the audience, and to promote astronomy and science literacy to the public.

For astronomers, the easily queriable JINAbase database of literature metal-poor star abundances has been established to provide the community with easy data access.
